title: Preparing for Release v0.8.0
body:
Remaining things to do:
- Update `ndarray` to `1.61.1`
- Make most dependencies depend on the specific version number (no surprises!)
- Cleanup `CHANGELOG.md`.
- [x] Wait for #906

title: extendr-ffi: remove unnecessary `static mut` from bindings
body:
Recent versions of Rust has started linting and posing warning on the use of `static mut`. Our bindings stems from `bindgen`, which does not have a mechanism to distinguish between `static`/`static mut` whenever it sees pointer.

Experience tells us the following: We are not to change the pointers of symbols nor environment variables. Therefore, these are no longer `static mut`, but `static`.

Update: Due to CI breakage on snapshot tests by the new stable release of Rust... This PR also has changes to the snapshot tests. All instances of `vec!` has been replaced with a `Vec::with_capacity` and `push`.

title: chore: set up R in docs CI step
body:
GHA runners removed R. So approximately 3 months ago the GHA to update docs has been failing. 

This PR uses the set up R action from the r-lib organization.

title: chore: ensure build.rs always succeeds
body: This PR ensures that the `build.rs` script for extendr-ffi _always_ completes. When no `R_HOME` is set to discover the R version available, the configure is set to the latest version (presently R 4.5).

title: Implement Index and IndexMut for 3D Array (RMatrix3D) (#897)
body:
* impelment index/indexmut for RMatrix3D

* Update changelog

* Update changelog

title: Implement Index and IndexMut for 3D Array (RMatrix3D)
body:
This PR adds implementations of `Index<[usize; 3]>` and `IndexMut<[usize; 3]>` for `RMatrix3D`. 

- Zero-based indexing for 3D arrays, allowing direct usage like `matrix[[r, c, d]]`.
- Includes doc tests demonstrating creation and mutation of 3D matrices.

This adds consistency with existing 2D matrix indexing.

title: fix: Backports, R-devel WARNINGs
body:
This PR addresses new WARNINGs in r-devel which require creating backports. 

Creating backports and new binding versions using libR-sys is a bit too much of a lift and is becoming too frequent of a task. To that end this PR introduces a new crate `extendr-ffi` and removes the dependency on `libR-sys` for both `extendr-api` and `extendr-engine`. 

`extendr-ffi` is a hand-curated set of bindings taken from `libR-sys`. It contains _only_ the bindings that are used by extendr and extendr-engine. Additionally it adds a `non-api` feature which is used by the extendr-api `non-api` feature. Previously the `non-api` feature in extendr-api could not compile due to manual removal of non-API functions from libR-sys. 

The new approach using extendr-api resolves this. Additionally, there is no need to use precomputed bindings simplifying the build process _greatly_ across all distributions. I suspect this will mean that integration with webR will be much simpler. 

Using `extendr-ffi` also can provide a path forward to closing https://github.com/extendr/extendr/issues/583

## Fixes 

- Closes https://github.com/extendr/extendr/issues/896 and all sub-issues
- Closes https://github.com/extendr/extendr/issues/889
- Closes https://github.com/extendr/extendr/issues/364
- Closes https://github.com/extendr/extendr/issues/677

## Deadline

CRAN packages that use extendr have a deadline of April 14th to remediate the issues. As such there is a bit of urgency to ensure that this gets addressed so we can try and make PRs to affected users' GitHub repositories.

title: chore: avoid r-devel check
body:
This PR :

- makes `cargo build` quiet in extendrtests so that CI for r-devel can finally pass. 
- adds `tools/msrv.R` to report rustc and cargo versions for r-devel
- addresses 0x1 error in 0 length vectors in r-devel

title: Extendr proc refactor - multiple `impl` blocks and struct converions
Chore/add from iterator implementations
body:
Housekeeping: add missing `FromIterator` implementation for vector types.
Allows for, e.g.,
```rust
let ints : Integers = (0..3).collect();
```

title: Add support for 4D and 5D matrices
body: - Closes #874

title: chore: bump faer to 0.20
body: This PR bumps the faer version to 0.20 to address issues with faer compilation on CI.

title: Use full path in macros
body: Currently, our macros assume  `use extendr_api::prelude::*`. It is an ongoing effort to remove this assumption. This PR does that.

title: Fix `cargo msrv` CI check
body: R installation was removed from latest OS image, so `cargo msrv verify` fails on `build` step.

title: Hotfix: Mishandling `NULL` pointer
body:
In #853, type-checking was added to `ExternalPtr<T>`. Previously, there were issues with processing `NULL` pointers, that we covered through a test. This test resided in `test-classes.R` of `extendrtests`. While the test still logically made sense after #853, the test would _panic_. For some reason, the `panic!` (due to an `unwrap()`) would not fail the test. We believe that this was unnoticed, because there was no signal of failure, outside the print log. The print log of R tests are not visible in the CI.

Now, the case of `NULL` pointer is handled in the type-checking code. It was an oversight, made possible by me being overly naive. But now, it is handled properly.

This is not a critical issue, but many exotic extendr code relies on passing of `NULL` pointers, so in a sense, it is critical to advanced use-cases.

title: Added conversions to tuples of up to size 12
body: Spoiler: The R construct `list()` is a very special. It is hard to find an equivalent Rust type. First, it is a contiguous data-layout, but it is the pointers, rather than actual data. The Rust equivalent could be `Vec>`. That is to say, it stores a list owned pointers, to any kind of data. I could make other Rust suggestions that would resemble `list()` better, but this one would do for now. The issue is the heterogeneity of the stored elements. They do not have to be the same thing. A fixed sized version of this is Rust tuples. A tuple of a certain size can contain any type, e.g. `(i32, i32, f64)`. Is equivalent to the unnamed list that contains `list(integer(), integer(), numeric())`. This PR adds conversions from `list(...)` to tuples. The tuple is of size 12, as this is chosen number by the `std` as well. It is important to say, that if `Robj` is any other type, like `integers(n=4), that does not mean the conversion would then target `(i32, i32, i32, i32)`. `Robj` must be `list()`/[`List`](https://extendr.github.io/extendr/extendr_api/wrapper/list/struct.List.html). If you're looking for such a conversion, see #856 instead, as that is more appropriate. - [x] ~~Things to do in a follow-up PR: All the extra functionality provided by `impl_try_from_robj`, such as `Option<(T0, ..., Tn)>`, etc.~~ This was necessary to make the PR work with `#[extendr]`-macro, so it is also applied.

title: Add conversions into `[T;N]`
body:
For a while, we have had the ability to take any Rust array, i.e. `[T; N]` and send that to R. See [`From<[T;N]>` in extendr-api](https://extendr.github.io/extendr/extendr_api/robj/struct.Robj.html#impl-From%3C%5BT;+N%5D%3E-for-Robj) for example.

But converting from say an R `integer(n=5)` to `[i32; 5]` should also be possible, despite the compile-time restriction. Because the array may be instantiated from a slice. This PR adds this capability to specify the expected vector size in the Rust API.

title: Soundness: `Robj` must be transparent
body: It is possible to use `std::mem::transmute` to go from a `SEXP` to, say, `&Robj`/`&mut Robj`. This is indeed necessary to make some API possible. See `Index` on `List` as an example. A follow-up PR for `Index` on `List` will come..

title: Generalize `HashMap` conversion
body: A named list can be thought of as a `HashMap<S, Robj>` where `S` is a string type, and `Robj` is an opaque type representing arbitrary R data. One may liken a `list()` to only having say `Doubles`s, where in this case, the desired representation would be `HashMap<S, Doubles>`. While this may seem as a limited example, it probably covers a lot of use cases for `list()`. This PR provides this conversion on `Robj` and `List` through the `TryFrom`-interface. It can also be used in `#[extendr]`-`fn`.

title: Try again: Type-checking `ExternalPtr<T>` by downcasting..
body:
This is an alternative to #852. This is clearly a more convoluted approach, but it seems to be the approach that Rust prefers.


~~This PR currently does not pass CI. It fundamentally changes how `ExternalPtr<T>` works. And there were assumptions about this in `#[extendr]`-impl, that needs to be adjusted.~~ Done.

title: Add `PartialEq` for `Rstr`
body:
Addition: It is not possible to compare `Rstr` to `Rstr` like the R interpreter does.

This PR adds that comparison. 

The case for this emerges when you want to take advantage of the fact that R has a string interner, which means that equality of strings can fall on the pointer address directly, instead of comparing the actual character bytes.

Use-case: 
Constructing a `HashSet<Rstr>` should be faster (with this) than constructing a `HashSet<&str>`. 
Caveat here is that the `Hash` for `Rstr` needs to be implemented, but this is a crucial bit...

title: Patch release PR: 0.7.1
body:
I just made a release of `extendr-macros`, `extendr-api` and `extendr-engine` on crates.io based on this PR.
Patched version to make things compile everywhere (CRAN, in CI, rextendr, etc.)

title: Mark is_valid_string as non-API
body:
Closes https://github.com/extendr/extendr/issues/841.

libR-sys PR https://github.com/extendr/libR-sys/pull/253 removed more non-API items. This needs to be reflected in `extendr-api`. At present if libR-sys 0.7.1 is used with extendr-api 0.7.0 compilation will fail. 


This PR marks the `is_valid_string()` and `is_valid_string_f()` trait methods as `non-api` feature.

title: Add missing impls to `ExternalPtr<T>`
body:
Missing impls that are useful in `#[extendr]`-impl, that should be accessible via `TryFrom<Robj>` too!

This was caught by @kbvernon and the code in the R test is from them.

Long explanation: The `#[extendr]` macro knows that it needs to convert from `&Robj`/`&mut Robj`. Usually, we don't do that. What we do is we implement things from `TryFrom<&Robj>` and piggyback that on `TryFrom<Robj>`, because `#[extendr]` usually just use `Robj` directly. 

And therefore, we forgot to include these impls.

title: update: Don't export `faer` and `ndarray` and their contents in `prelude`
Don't rely on `prelude` in extendr-macros
body:
There are a few places, where we refer to objects, as if they are in scope, but they may not be.

This was seen on r-polars and is related to #818.

title: Documentation: Adjusting `README`
body:
I would like to clean-up the `README` pages of extendr packages.

First we have `README`s that appear when navigating on GitHub:
https://github.com/extendr/extendr/blob/master/README.md
https://github.com/extendr/extendr/blob/master/extendr-api/README.md
https://github.com/extendr/extendr/blob/master/extendr-engine/README.md
https://github.com/extendr/extendr/blob/master/extendr-macros/README.md
https://github.com/extendr/extendr/blob/master/xtask/README.md

Then there are front-pages of doc.rs for the various crates
https://github.com/extendr/extendr/blob/master/extendr-api/src/lib.rs
https://github.com/extendr/extendr/blob/master/extendr-engine/src/lib.rs
https://github.com/extendr/extendr/blob/master/extendr-macros/src/lib.rs


After discussing this with @kbvernon, I think we should:

- Don't have too many code-examples in the GitHub `README`, but refer to docs.rs (for stable) / extendr-website hosted docs (for development), and those `lib.rs` files, should have the code-heavy introductions.
- Link to the website and the user-guide on each of the GitHub `README`s.

title: CHANGELOG
body:
- Update the version (and seal previous version)
- Escape this part, as it looks weird on the website, see the first entry at this link https://extendr.github.io/changelog.html#changed

title: Improve derive macros
body:
- `#[extendr]`-`impl` assumed that the `Error` available is `extendr_api::Error`. Now, it is explicit.
  - Same with `ExternalPtr`
  - Same with `Result`
- `mut` on `args` is not necessary in `wrappers.rs`

~~I've got a few more improvements that I've found that I want to migrate over...~~
Actually, I'll save that to another PR.

These were discovered when trying to update r-polars to extendr 0.7.0.
https://github.com/pola-rs/r-polars/pull/1154

I think these should be merged ASAP, and we can consider a patch-release. We'll release when a few more issues reveal themselves in the next few weeks.

title: JOSS paper citation
body:
JOSS paper on extendr was just published.
So now we can have a badge and a citation file.

title: Add tests for extendr features
body:
In PR #812 we removed CI that builds bindgen bindings. However, these tests were actually also secretly testing each feature of extendr. 

This PR modifies the `matrix.config` to add a `features` section to make it explicit which features are being tested.

title: Lower MSRV for CRAN Compliance
body:
This PR lowers extendr's MSRV to 1.65 making it compatible with CRAN.

It is not no longer possible to build bindings by way of `cargo`-features.

The feature `non-api` is fully broken, and enabling it won't compile.

title: Fix unnecessary note when running CMD CHECK
body:
Changes the URL so we don't get:

```
Found the following (possibly) invalid URLs:
URL: https://opensource.org/license/mit/ (moved to https://opensource.org/license/mit)
    From: README.md
    Status: 200
    Message: OK
```

title: [internal] Adjust path for `extendrtests`
body:
The path in `tests/extendrtests/src/rust/Cargo.toml` is very obscure.

I don't know who it serves.

With `xtask`, we adjust this in a process, to make it work with `devtools` and `rcmdcheck`.

Now, I ask that we merge this, so that it works when one is developing extendr, in the repository as workspace/working-directory, and when in vscode,

```json
{
    "rust-analyzer.linkedProjects": [
        "tests/extendrtests/src/rust/Cargo.toml",
    ]
}
```

I ask you to merge this as soon as possible, because I'm tired of things being set in an unhelpful way.

title: [urgent] Update non-API for CRAN
body:
CRAN compliance PR.

Background: CRAN has new requirements for what is non-API. These requirements just came up and became defacto law of the land. They are not tied to any R release. We just have to deal with it.

We pulled non-API list in 
https://github.com/extendr/libR-sys/pull/248

This PR syncs `libR-sys` with this commit.

- Hid previous available functionality behind `non-api` feature. It means, if you want it, you may compile `extendr-api` with `feature = ["non-api"]`. This requires you to build your own bindings by way of `libR-sys` as wel.
- Moved all doc-tests to `non_api_tests`, and in order to make that work, I had to add an entry for it in `extendr-api/Cargo.toml`. Note that the `optional`-module in integration tests doesn't work. And it needs to also have an entry to work.
- I also added `required-features`, but this doesn't run the test _unless_ the feature is provided to the `cargo test`-call. So these tests are present, but won't run. We have to have a broader conversation about testing `non-api`. For now, this is a patch, that allows us to rediscover missing features if users want them.

title: Support for `Option<Strings>`, `Option<Doubles>`, and friends
Less ambigious return type for colnames/rownames
body:
Follow-up to #796

Instead of returning `Robj`, we should aim to be more descriptive of the returned result. For `colnames`/`rownames` it is a bit obvious that it should be `NULL` or a character vector.

_This uncovered something_ that our vector types `Integers`, `Doubles` etc. are not implemented for `From<Robj> for Option<r-vector-type>`. That could be a follow-up to this.

- [ ] Partial dependence on #802.

title: Updates libR-sys
body: Closes #797

title: Update main `README.md`
body:
The extendR repo is probably the first point of entry for many people curious about extendr.

But we don't have the right linking to new users. 

This addresses this for now.

title: Remove `libR-sys` from extendrtests permanently
body:
Fixes #787 

As agreed, we now prefer `R_HOME` in `tests/extendrtests` or if R is available from `PATH`.

It is reasonable enough, to assume that the contributors to extendR, will have configured their terminal to have R available there.

title: Bug fix: Don't use `libR_sys` in macros
body: Fixes #786

title: Added mutable slices from `AsTypedSlice` to `TryFrom`
Updating documentation everywhere
body:
There are many outdated statements in the documentation.
Some are downright wrong.

I think the best way to review this is commit-by-commit

title: [urgent] fix: relying on specific behavior for `List::iter`
body:
Discovered by @kbvernon: We removed this behaviour in #761, but it is used in `List::iter`. Basically, a `StrIter` can be initiated without any strings.

This points to `StrIter` being overloaded already, but we have to fix this bug sooner rather than later.

Here's the fix.

title: [error handling]: Ensure all arguments are dropped
body:
Another entry in fixing unwinding: In the C-wrappers, all `Robj` derived from `SEXP`s should be moved to the closure, that evaluates the user-provided function. This way, when the closure is finished, either by panic or otherwise, the arguments all dropped.

This actually solves 90% of the problem we have with unwinding.

There are others that does it similarly: See https://github.com/jrobsonchase/easy_ffi/blob/master/src/lib.rs#L128 from the `easy_ffi` crate.

title: STANDALONE: Removing unnecessary clones
body: These conversions are defined on `&Robj` already, so we don't need to clone anyways.

title: extendrtests: added null externalptr test
body: Follow-up on #709, as we didn't actually add a test for this in `tests/extendrtests`.

title: bug: removed `&[u32]` interpretation of `Robj`
body:
In `AsTypedSlice`, we assume that one may convert a `&[i32]` to a `&[u32]`. That works, unless any of the
`i32` being _reinterpreted_ are negative values. This was done in #763, but then a _mutable slice_ would not work either.
For now, we have to remove these, and only adopt them, when we can only implement a reference access, and said
reference access may only work on non-negative slices.

title: STANDALONE: Re-use `ExternalPtr` creation method
body:
This PR cleans up the creation of `ExternalPtr<T>` from `Robj`.
First, we are following @yutannihilation's advice, and no longer doing the insufficient,
stringly-typed type-checking. Second, we are re-using the definitions that is also used in `#[extendr]`-impl.

This depends on merging of

- [x] #765

title: STANDALONE: `ExternalPtr` is a pointer
body:
One cannot `PartialEq` or `Clone` the `ExternalPtr<T>` in the traditional sense, by relying on the 
trait on `T`. Instead, we treat `ExternalPtr` like a pointer. This behaviour is now documented, and the
alternative way to perform comparison is also mentioned.

title: STANDALONE: faer isn't in the prelude
body: Part of _quick_ PRs to just adjust some things we have not noticed.

title: [urgent!] `#[extendr]`-impl requires `libR-sys`
body:
Currently on `master`,  `#[extendr]`-impl requires that the user have `libR-sys` as a dependency to compile. **This is a big problem**

The culprit is the extraction of a reference / mutable reference from `Robj`. We use something
from `libR-sys` directly, thus the user needs to have `libR-sys` available.
We do not export `libR-sys`, so we can't depend on it by way of `extendr-api`. Meaning, there is no `pub use libR_sys;` in `extendr-api`. I don't think we should do that either.

Instead, I think we should unify the interface of `#[extendr]`-impl to fully embrace `ExternalPtr<T>`.

This is what this PR is about!

## Details

I take a `&Robj`, turn that (unsafely) to `&ExternalPtr<T>`, and from there I extract (unsafely) the `&T`.
Similarly, this is done for `&mut T`.
To ensure that this is okay, we have to make `ExternalPtr<T>` transparent.

**Going from `&Robj` to `ExternalPtr<T>`**: The `Robj` could be something else than an `externalptr`. One could have put in a `list()` instead. Thus, we make a type-check on `externalptr`-type.

**Going from `&ExternalPtr<T>` to `&T`**: The pointer may be `NULL`.

All of these conditions has been unified in an error-aware chain of calls. All the low-level pointer
manipulations has been replaced by Rust approved abstraction.
_There is one more abstraction that we can employ, the `NonNull<T>` one.. But let us wait on that for another PR.

Finally, the finalizer has been removed, because we can rely on `ExternalPtr<T>`, and its clean way of doing this. To that end, `ExternalPtr<T>` was missing an `Attributes`-impl.

## Conclusion

Actually there is way more: We urgently need to approve this, but what is more important,
is to remove the dependency of `libR-sys` from our integration test crate `tests/extendrtests/src/rust`. This can be done, but it is going to be a bit contentious. I'll do that in a follow-up PR.

title: Faster string conversion
body:
This PR is meant to improve how we convert character-vectors to rust strings.

First, observe that
- Length of `STRSXP` is the number of embedded `CHARSXP` in the character-vector
- Length of `CHARSXP` are the number of characters in a string. 

Then, let's first look at `to_str`. This function scans a C-string until it meets `\nul`, which
is then what determines the length of the string. Thus, for every string, we iterate through all the
bytes, until we find `0`/`\nul`. This is unnecessary. Then, there is the wonky conversion `sexp_to_str`.
Removing those two is what leads to the rest of the PR.

Every symbol is a permanent object, that contains a protected string, and `PRINT_NAME` refers to the underlying `CHARSXP`. 

- [ ] Remove all the `assert_eq!` for checking if the string is a `CHARSXP`. I don't think it is worth it.


This PR was largely motivated by this post https://github.com/extendr/extendr/pull/646#issuecomment-1752582837.

title: Clean-up after #759
body:
- Merged tests that were made for `FromRobj` and `TryFrom` separately.
- [x] This change depends on https://github.com/extendr/rextendr/pull/354

title: `use-try-from = true` as default
body:
Today is the day: No more `FromRobj`, only `TryFrom` from now on.

This is a massive PR, and I request your highest attention and diligence on this one.

I had to re-adjust a few things, but I don't think it is too much. 

- Moved `ExtendrOptions` to its own file, because it is shared amongst multiple sub-macros.
And will be used in more macros later
- `FromRobj` used to have conversions from `StrIter`, `HashMap<_,Robj>` (to lists), and stuff like that I ported over.
- The `RMatrix` stuff was not defined on `&Robj`, instead it was defined on `Robj` directly. This isn't what we do elsewhere, so I mimic exactly what we do there. I can't re-use the macros, because of the presence of a generic. 

That's it. Most of the code is trimming compile-macro-tests, wrapper generation, macro-snapshot, integration tests.. 

### Post Merge Actions

- [x] After this PR is merged, the focus should be on updating `rextendr` in https://github.com/extendr/rextendr/pull/354
- [x] Once that happens, then a new PR should be made to remove the dependence on this PR's branch in CI

title: Convert integer-ish values based on `f64::classify()`
body: Switch to `f64::classify()` to determine what type of float we are dealing with. Simplifies handling of `NaN`, subnormals, both `-0.0` and `0.0`, as well as infinities.

title: Fix integerish conversions
body:
Fixes #720.
- Rework scalar `f64` (`Rfloat`) to integer type conversions (both `FromRobj` and `TryFrom`) by extracting all logic into a single `FloatToInt` trait. 
- Properly handle all edge cases like `NA`, over-/under-flow, subnormality
- Disallow rounding casts that result in loss of accuracy (e.g., `4.2f64` no longer maps to `4i32`)
- Allow only `f64` values that are exactly representable by target integer type

Also update `xtask`:
- `cargo extendr devtools-test` now gained `-f`/`--filter` option that controls which tests to execute. Value is passed verbatim to `filter` parameter of `devtools::test()`

title: Update CHANGELOG
body: We haven't updated changelog since #706 or #754

title: Various maintenance
body:
- [x] Added `non-api` option that exposes functionality that was considered API prior to R 4.4. We are marking these `unsafe`. This is considered a breaking change.
- [x] As we are now testing multiple versions of R, actively, we may switch to R environments that does not have all the necessary packages for development.
This PR adds a check and prints a message with the useful command-line instruction to install missing packages.
- [x] I've also added instructions for using development versions of extendr, with rextendr in `tests/extendrtests/README.md`. 
- [x] This PR became contingent on this https://github.com/extendr/rextendr/pull/352

title: `extendr-macros`: Accept argument alias with `mut` in front
`xtask`: Minor documentation addition
body:
A typical workflow for making a PR to extendr may involve


```sh
cargo extendr document
cargo extendr devtools-test
cargo extendr devtools-test -a 
```

(and maybe even `cargo extendr r-cmd-check`)

However, when looking at the overview presented to you by
`cargo extendr`, you won't see "snapshots" anywhere.
Unless of course, you wrote `cargo extendr devtools-test -h`,
where you'd see `--accept-snapshot`.

_But what generates them?_ Well `cargo extendr devtools-test`-invocation does!

title: Various documentation updates
body: These are plucked from the fork I've been toying with. I'm open to changes, but mostly I want move this along

title: Add `Attributes` to all vector types
body:
It is not possible to set the attributes to vector-types. This is currently achievable by converting to `Robj`, setting attribute, and converting back. This indirection should not be necessary. 

Update: This was brought on due to the desire to include

```rs
fn as_is_col(x: impl IntoRobj) -> Robj {
    let robj = x.into_robj();
    List::from_values([robj])
        .into_robj()
        .set_class(&["AsIs"])
        .unwrap()
}
```
(due to @JosiahParry) as an analogue for `I()` in R.

title: Replaces `SEXPTYPE` and `Rboolean` to the new `enum`-versions
body: This relies on https://github.com/extendr/libR-sys/pull/233

title: nit: an early-return branch should also UNPROTECT()

title: Add `TryFrom` for `ExternalPtr`
body:
We want to move away from `FromRobj`. On this journey, we have a few places, where there is hard-coded some logic, that is `from_robj`, etc.
This PR introduces the `#[extendr]` on `impl`-blocks using `use_try_from = true`. To that end, a lot of other wrapper-macros needs adjustment.

I'd appreciate thorough investigation of this, but I've spent months already figuring out if this works or not. And it should work.

title: `#[extendr]`-impl: Return the right reference
body:
Following the polishing of `ExternalPtr` is this PR on returning the _right_ reference.

First, we remove the ability to take `&T` and make `ExternalPtr<T>`. This is a flawed construct: Making an `ExternalPtr` is not just wrapping a pointer, it is also signing a pointer up for destruction. Converting a `&T` to `ExternalPtr<T>` may cause spurious double-free events.

The Rules of ExternalPtr are simple:

* From an owned type, one may create an Owned Pointer, and from an owned pointer, one can instantiate a true `ExternalPtr`.
* From `&ExternalPtr<T>` you can create `&T`, and similarly for `&mut ExternalPtr<T>` and `&mut T`.

So, should there be no references used or returned? A reference that comes from a true `ExternalPtr<T>` may be used. We embed this logic on the wrapping function, rather than do any C-crimes.

If a reference corresponds to any of the `ExternalPtr<T>` in the argument list, then that is returned. 

Fixes #725

Depends on
- [x] #765 
- [x] https://github.com/extendr/extendr/pull/766

title: Fix `#[extendr]` conversions into `Dataframe<T>`
body: Addressing #715

title: extendr-impl: Support returning `&Self` and `&mut Self`
body:
Fixes #614 

This allows `extendr-impl` types to return `&Self` / `&mut Self`.
The logic is, that the `Robj` that was provided to the wrapper, is itself a reference-type,
that should be returned to R, instead of recreating the ExternalPtr.

For R users, this unlocks defining pipe-friendly interfaces using `extendr-impl`.

@sorhawell I believe this was a blocker for you, and making a pipe-friendly polars interface, right?

title: `xtask` add more features
body:
I've added a bunch of extra features to the `xtask`. There are many changes lines, but these should be complete, in the sense that they won't require too much exploration to review.

Also, I'm trying to out as a out to migrate changes from the "fork" to `master`.

- Added a `cargo extendr fmt` that uses `cargo fmt` / `rustfmt` on both the crates in the workspace, plus `tests/extendrtests/src/rust` as well. We rarely format that integration-test crate.
- Added `cargo extendr devtools-test -a` which will "accept" the newly generated macros from a given build. We will see the changes in the PR, but this will help contributors. The workflow is imagined to be: `cargo extendr devtools-test`, that then tests things, and a potential new `macro-snapshot.md` is generated. Then one is supposed to call `cargo extendr devtools-test -a` to accept the snapshot, and perform testing _again_, just in case.
- Added `cargo extendr document`, which is a feature to run `rextendr::document()` for the `tests/extendrtests`-package. In the fork, I've vendored the `rextendr` crate, which makes it possible to have a consistent contributor-experience, if one is changing `rextendr` simultaneously.

title: fixex `throw_r_error` may crash R session #716
body: Looking at the records, I had seen this bug before in 11ea513251f71889318d580a93d15200a7d83bf5, but I wasn't sure what was going on. Now, I'm very confident that this was because of a PR to use `CStr` more, but the feature-gated `result_list` wasn't tested, or something like that.

title: followup to #657
body:
A rebase (on my end) reverted these changes https://github.com/extendr/extendr/pull/657/commits/ba567188235ca1aeb1d6e8569e0971e3f918b845

There was dead-code / redundant code that should have been deleted, and they were, but then a rebase further down the line re-did them. Sorry.

title: Implement IntoRobj for Dataframe<T>
body:
This PR closes https://github.com/extendr/extendr/issues/710

It implements `IntoRobj` by returning the inner `Robj`. The associate test asserts that the returned Robj is equal to the Robj provided by `df.as_robj().clone()`.

title: ci: Upload results of r-cmd-check
body:
We continue to see sporadic errors on ci.

The logs from r-cmd-check are not uploaded, when it fails.

We use our own custom invocation of `r-cmd-check` due to path issues or something or another I've never understood why we even have to be bogged down by rstudio path-nonsense.

Anyways, upload scheme adapted from https://github.com/r-lib/actions/blob/v2/check-r-package/action.yaml

Let us see if it works.

title: fix ci: r-devel now uses rtools44 by default
body: Following in the steps of extendr/libR-sys#220. This is affecting CI right now.

title: [Doc] mention `i32` in RMatrix::new_matrix()
body: This PR mentions `i32` as a possible numeric scalar type

title: Introduce optional faer support
body: This PR introduces optional support for `faer::Mat<f64>` into and from a `Robj` in order to integrate with the [faer](https://github.com/sarah-ek/faer-rs) crate.

body: Partial conditions (when `else` clause is dropped) passed `''` among parameters instead of nothing, which subsequently led to broken invocations of `cargo`.

title: Bump baptiste0928/cargo-install from 2 to 3

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
Bumps [baptiste0928/cargo-install](https://github.com/baptiste0928/cargo-install) from 2 to 3.
Release notes

Sourced from baptiste0928/cargo-install's releases.

v3.0.0

Added

  • Runner os version is included in the cache key. (#21)

Changed

  • Breaking: The action now runs on Node.js 20.
  • Dependencies have been updated.

v2.2.0

Added

  • Support alternative registries with the registry and index input parameters.

Changed

  • Crate versions are fetched from the sparse index instead of the crates.io API.

v2.1.0

Added

  • Git installation is now supported with the git input parameter. You can specify a branch, tag or commit hash. (#14)

Usage:

- name: Install cargo-sort from git
  uses: baptiste0928/cargo-install@v2
  with:
    crate: cargo-sort
    git: https://github.com/devinr528/cargo-sort
    tag: v1.0.9  # `branch` and `commit` are also supported
Changelog

Sourced from baptiste0928/cargo-install's changelog.

[3.0.0] - 2024-02-01

Added

  • Runner os version is included in the cache key. (issue #21)

Changed

  • Breaking: The action now runs on Node.js 20.
  • Dependencies have been updated.

[2.2.0] - 2023-09-07

Added

  • Support alternative registries with the registry and index input parameters.

Changed

  • Crate versions are fetched from the sparse index instead of the crates.io API.

[2.1.0] - 2023-06-09

Added

  • Git installation is now supported with the git input parameter. You can specify a branch, tag or commit hash.

[2.0.0] - 2023-03-23

Added

  • Name and version are shown in the cache key. This allow to identify cache entries in the cache management UI more easily.

Changed

  • Breaking: The action now runs on Node.js 16.
  • Breaking: Versions without semver range (e.g. 1.2.3) are now considered as exact versions.
  • Breaking: Set --locked by default. locked input is no longer deprecated.
  • Various code improvements and refactoring.

[1.3.1] - 2023-02-15

Fixed

  • Use semver instead of compare-versions to fix version resolution issues.
  • Dependencies have been updated. This removes the warning about set-output being deprecated.

[1.3.0] - 2022-06-14

Added

  • Add args input to add additional arguments to the cargo install command.

Deprecated

  • locked input is deprecated, use the args input with --locked instead.

[1.2.0] - 2022-03-16

Added

  • Add locked input to add --locked argument to cargo install command.

title: Opinionated edits to the first part of the paper
body: I made some edits to the paper. I found inconsistencies between statements at the beginning and in the middle, as well as a fair portion of duplication.

title: Update paper.md
body: Claus Wilke edits

title: Suggested edits to the paper for structure, clarity and brevity
body:
I've suggested some fairly substantial changes to the paper, but some of this was just moving text around - I tried to move text in the first commit and then edit in later commits so that you can follow my thought process. In particular I:

- Rationalised the structure so that appropriate text was under appropriate sections (and renamed/combined some sections, where appropriate)
- Eliminated repetition between sections to condense the paper
- Re-wrote the summary to bring out the important points of the software
- Made several edits throughout for wording and clarity

There are a couple of comments where I had questions, but otherwise this looks in good shape to me now.

I hope this is useful and look forward to hopefully contributing further to this project in the future!

title: Use public RSPM in both setup-r workflows
body:
This PR changes the use-public-rspm flag to true where it was previously false. 

RSPM will serve binaries when available. Otherwise it will default to source installations. 

Was there a reason why this was set false?

title: Clarify .inherits() behavior
body:
This PR improves the documentation for the `.inherits()` method to clarify that the method does not support implicit classes.

Closes https://github.com/extendr/extendr/issues/68

title: Fix compilation with features `result_list` and `result_condition`
body: Fix #650, supersedes #652

title: fix: should not use `@docType "package"`
body:
Fix #684

The existence of this makes it impossible to use `"_PACKAGE"` in packages where extendr-wrapper.R is located, like pola-rs/r-polars#705

title: Tiny improvent to `Raw`
body:
Based on the discussion on Discord, tweak `Raw` initialization:
- Abstract initialization into a separate method
- Use `.fill()` to initialize empty `Raw`
- Use `copy_to_slice()` to copy data
